newsitem.title: USA: USDA considers return to on-farm grain stockpile.
newsitem.headline: USDA considers return to on-farm grain stockpile.

text.p: In what would potentially be a reversal of a new law minimizing the federal role in agriculture, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said Friday that creation of a U.S. grain stockpile on farms is worth consideration.

The Republican-run Congress eliminated the Farmer Owned Reserve, the major U.S. grain-stockpiling program, as part of this year's "Freedom to Farm" law. The reserve gave farmers nearly three years to sell their grain.
"I do think it is appropriate to look at the area of reserves," Glickman said during a telephone news conference with farm broadcasters, pointing to concerns about volatile prices.

"I don't know what we'll come up with but I would be interested in working with Congress and, again, it has to be a bipartisan Congress or we won't get this thing done," he said when asked if the reserve would be reauthorized.

Proponents say reserves would stablize prices and assure an adequate supply during times of small crops. Critics say the real story has been the opposite -- reserves lock up grain supplies and set a ceiling on prices because buyers know the trigger price that will release a flood of grain.

In remarks from the World Food Summit in Rome, Glickman said "responsible reserves" were among four farm policy issues for Congress in the new year. The others were landlord-tenant relations, farm credit rules and "risk management" tools.
Nebraska Sen. Bob Kerrey, a Democrat, was interested in restoring the Farmer Owned Reserve, an aide said.
"It's hard to say if it would be in the cards," said Bob Peterson of the Coalition for a Competitive Food and Agriculture System group. "We'll have to see what ideas people would offer."

The Farmer Owned Reserve allowed up to 1.35 billion bushels of wheat and feed grains to be held in storage for up to 33 months and paid farmers a monthly storage fee while they waited for more attractive market prices. Still in effect is the Food Security Commodity Reserve, which holds up to 4 million metric tons, or about 147 million bushels, for hunger relief worldwide.

Private consultant John Schnittker said the issue of a grain reserve might become linked to debate over higher loan rates -- a frequent request from farm-state lawmakers -- and extending the nine-month loan available to farmers at harvest time.
The consumer group Public Voice for Food and Health Policy has promoted creation of a grain reserve as a standby against weather damage to U.S. crops.
